criteria: Understanding of Relative vs. Absolute Location
descriptions: Student cannot identify any of the required locations (local community, California, USA, seven continents, and four oceans) on a map or globe.
Student can identify only 1-2 of the required locations with accuracy.
Student can identify 3-4 of the required locations with reasonable accuracy, but makes several errors.
Student can identify most (5-6) of the required locations with minor errors in precision.
Student can accurately identify all of the required locations on a map or globe with only slight imprecision.
Student can precisely and accurately identify all of the required locations on a map or globe, demonstrating a strong understanding of global geography.
Student does not demonstrate the ability to use a map or globe to locate places.
Student attempts to use a map/globe but struggles significantly with basic features (e.g., finding places).
Student shows some ability to use a map/globe, but requires assistance and makes frequent errors in using scale, key, or coordinates.
Student independently uses map/globe features with general accuracy, but may need occasional help with more complex aspects.
Student skillfully uses map/globe features such as scale, key, and coordinates to accurately locate places.
Student expertly uses map/globe features to accurately locate places and can explain the significance of map projections and spatial relationships.
Student does not demonstrate any understanding of the difference between relative and absolute location.
Student shows a limited awareness of relative vs. absolute location, but cannot articulate the difference.
Student can somewhat distinguish between relative and absolute location, but struggles to apply the concepts.
Student can generally explain the difference between relative and absolute location and provide simple examples.
Student clearly understands and explains the difference between relative and absolute location, using relevant examples related to the identified locations.
Student demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of relative and absolute location, explaining the nuances of how these concepts are used in geography and real-world scenarios.
